conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to the back right, considering both position and size changes.

The image shows four objects on a green surface: a pink/red circular cake or dessert (shadow A), a small dark object or hole (shadow B), a roll of medical bandage with a red cross (shadow C), and a thin ring or bracelet (shadow D).
Each object casts a shadow labeled with a corresponding letter (A, B, C, D).
In the first image, all shadows appear to be cast slightly to the left and toward the front of their objects, indicating the light source is initially positioned to the front right.
The light source is moving from front-right to back-right, meaning light rays will now hit objects from behind rather than from the front.
Shadows always move in the opposite direction from the light source, so shadows will shift toward the front left as the light moves to the back right.
Shadow size depends on the distance between the light source and the object, the height of the object, and the angle of the light rays.
Shadow A (from the cake) will move toward the front left and likely elongate as the light moves farther behind it, extending further in front of the cake.
Shadow B (from the small dark object) will move toward the front left and elongate similar to shadow A, with the change being proportionally more noticeable due to its small size.

Shadow C (from the medical bandage roll) will move toward the front left and elongate significantly due to the height of the cylindrical roll, with its vertical dimension creating a longer shadow as light comes from behind.

Shadow D (from the ring) will move toward the front left and may show minimal elongation due to the ring's thin profile, with its circular shape potentially creating an elliptical shadow that becomes more elongated.
In the second image, all shadows have moved forward (toward the bottom of the image) and leftward.
In the second image, the shadows have become more elongated, especially for the taller objects.
In the second image, the ring's shadow (D) shows the least dramatic change but still follows the same pattern of movement and elongation.
When the light source moves to the back right, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move toward the front left of their respective objects.
When the light source moves to the back right, all shadows will become longer/more elongated as the light now hits the objects from behind.
Taller objects (especially the bandage roll) will show more dramatic shadow elongation when the light source moves to the back right.
